import React, { useState } from 'react'; import { HelpCircle, X, Info } from 'lucide-react'; const ScoringGuide = () => { const [showHelp, setShowHelp] = useState(false); return ( <>
{/* Header with Help Icon */}

Assessment Scoring Guide

{/* Scoring Image */}
{/* Note about N/A */}

ðŸ“Œ Note: Select 0 (N/A) if a question does not apply to your business. These responses will not be included in your score calculation.

{/* Help Modal - Pop out above everything */} {showHelp && (
{/* Modal Header */}

Understanding: Clear, Documented, & Transferable

{/* Modal Content - Scrollable */}
{/* Clarity Section */}

1. Clarity

The concept, process, system, or strategy is well-understood and articulated by the owner and key stakeholders. There is shared language and alignment around what it is, why it matters, and how it functions. Clarity means there is no ambiguity or confusion â€” if you asked three people in the organization about it, they would describe it the same way.

Examples of Clarity:

  • âœ“ The company's value proposition is clearly defined and communicated
  • âœ“ Leadership roles and decision-making authority are clearly understood
  • âœ“ The succession timeline and criteria are clearly established
  • âœ“ Financial goals and performance metrics are clearly communicated to the team
{/* Documentation Section */}

2. Documented

The process, system, policy, or strategy is written down in a permanent, accessible format. Documentation transforms clarity from memory or habit into tangible reference material that can be reviewed, updated, and standardized. It moves knowledge from "in someone's head" to{' '} "in the manual".

Examples of Documentation:

  • âœ“ Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) exist in written form
  • âœ“ Organizational charts, role descriptions, and reporting structures are documented
  • âœ“ Financial policies, approval workflows, and budgeting processes are in writing
  • âœ“ Succession plans, governance structures, and strategic plans are formally recorded
{/* Transferability Section */}

3. Transferable

The documented process, system, or knowledge can be successfully handed off to someone else with minimal loss of effectiveness. Transferability means the business, role, or responsibility does not depend on one person's presence, memory, or skill â€” it can function independently or under new leadership. This is the ultimate test of business maturity and exit readiness.

Examples of Transferability:

  • âœ“ A new employee can perform the role by following the documented process
  • âœ“ The business continues to operate smoothly when the owner is absent
  • âœ“ A buyer or successor can step in and understand how to run the company
  • âœ“ Key client relationships are managed through systems, not just personal rapport
{/* Summary */}

ðŸŽ¯ The Progression to Exit Readiness

Everyone understands it

DOCUMENTATION

â†’
TRANSFERABILITY
Anyone can execute it
{/* Modal Footer */}
)} ); }; export default ScoringGuide;
